title: Active Directory Enumeration & Attack Path Discovery
subtitle: From baseline inventory to privilege escalation graphing
learning_objectives: Execute baseline enumeration of users, groups, and computers without disrupting production
Correlate group memberships and delegation settings to identify privilege escalation paths
Use PowerView and SharpHound modules with minimal footprint and auditable safeties
Interpret BloodHound-style graphs to prioritize escalation targets and mitigations
Document enumeration findings for blue team remediation and hardening workstreams
Apply OPSEC safeguards that respect rules of engagement while collecting directory intelligence

content_blocks.title: Recon With Purpose

content.text: Enumeration is not a noisy treasure hunt. Treat it like digital archaeology: brush lightly, capture context, and respect the artifacts you uncover. Your mindset should balance curiosity, discipline, and empathy for the defenders who will inherit your findings.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Approach AD recon like a careful explorer, not a bull in a china shop.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Experienced operators run quiet, well-documented discovery because they know the same data powers defensive remediation.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: What safeguards will you enable before running your first command?

content_blocks.title: Core Enumeration Workflows

content.text:
## Three Chunks of Enumeration
- **Baseline discovery** – Native tools, LDAP queries, and documentation review to understand the forest.
- **Privilege mapping** – PowerView and SharpHound sweeps that spotlight toxic combinations, SPNs, and delegation edges.
- **Graph analysis** – Translating JSON exports into visuals and Cypher queries that prioritize escalation routes.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Learn the flow: inventory, map privilege, then visualize paths.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Purple teams align red and blue playbooks around these three phases to stay synchronized.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which stage do you currently feel least confident about?

content_blocks.title: Enumeration Mnemonic

content.text:
### L.E.A.P.
- **L**ist scope and safeties.
- **E**numerate with native tools first.
- **A**utomate with SharpHound when justified.
- **P**resent findings as graphs plus mitigations.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Keep LEAP handy so you do not skip the fundamentals under pressure.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Teams that follow LEAP produce reports defenders can act on immediately.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which LEAP step do you tend to rush? How will you slow it down?

content_blocks.title: Field Example: Legacy Group Chain

content.text: During an EU financial engagement, a red team discovered that a legacy "Server Operators" group still retained nested membership granting Domain Admin. The finding emerged after combining LDAP queries with SharpHound exports. The blue team used the same dataset to remove obsolete delegations, cutting twenty-two unnecessary privileged accounts.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Enumeration revealed a risk and empowered defenders to close it.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: This case study came from a jointly facilitated purple-team exercise.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: How would you package a similar finding for executive stakeholders?

content_blocks.title: Plan an Enumeration Run

content.text:
1. List the pre-flight checks you will complete before running SharpHound (scope confirmation, safeties, detection contacts).
2. Draft the exact PowerView and SharpHound commands you will execute for a low and a medium noise collection.
3. Describe how you will package, encrypt, and hand off data to the blue team.
Record your plan in the CyberLearn project notebook and set a review reminder.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Mentally rehearse the workflow before touching a lab keyboard.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Operators use dry runs to prevent live engagements from derailing.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: What part of the plan felt most fragile? How can you reinforce it?

content_blocks.title: Teach Back the Findings

content.text:
### Reflect & Teach
- Draft a short debrief describing how you would explain your enumeration approach to senior defenders.
- List two mitigation actions you would recommend based on common findings.
- Identify one detection analytic you would propose to catch future misuse.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Teaching the workflow cements the reasoning behind each step.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Purple-team hotwashes often follow this exact agenda.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Who will you share your debrief with this week?

post_assessment.question: What is the advantage of combining LDAP queries with SharpHound data?
options: LDAP is faster so SharpHound becomes unnecessary
LDAP provides live state verification that complements graph exports
SharpHound outputs are only accurate when LDAP is disabled
The combination hides enumeration activity from defenders
post_assessment.explanation: LDAP queries validate assumptions and help prioritise SharpHound findings with real-time context.

post_assessment.question: Which OPSEC consideration is most critical when running PowerView in production?
options: Always run as Domain Admin to avoid errors
Throttle queries, randomise timing, and clean artifacts
Broadcast your commands to the security team
Disable antivirus first to speed execution
post_assessment.explanation: Controlled query rates, staggered timing, and disciplined cleanup reduce detection risk while respecting engagement rules.

post_assessment.question: Why should enumeration findings be documented for blue teams?
options: To prove the red team is smarter
So defenders can validate and remediate risky configurations
To avoid having to run SharpHound again
post_assessment.explanation: Transparent documentation closes the learning loop and enables defenders to harden the environment efficiently.
